entry.title: Enhanced Validation for Concurrent Employment and Global Assignment Conflicts - 2H 2025
entry.content:
As part of our ongoing efforts to ensure data consistency and data quality we have added validation to avoid concurrent employment and global assignment conflicts. 

As of 2H 2025 when adding a global assignment to an employee with a concurrent employment the system will show a validation warning about the two conflicting employments:

The same will apply if you add a concurrent employment to an employee on a global assignment:

Why are we doing this?

As per our implementation guide, a global assignment and a concurrent employment cannot be applied to the same employee at the same time (Types of Employment | SAP Help Portal) .  We are introducing this change to ensure the system and documentation are aligned and to reduce the possibility of data inconsistencies. 

What do you need to know?

The validation will come into effect in 2H 2025 if you try to add an active concurrent employment and global assignment at the same time.

This change will not impact employees who already have active concurrent employments and global assignments which exist at the same time. 

This change does not impact on future dated records, for example, an employee has a concurrent employment which ends on 31st December and they go on a global assignment on 1st January

We have introduced the validation as a warning message to give customers time to adjust their processes accordingly. It is planned in 1H 2026 to change the validation warning to an error. If you have a business scenario which allows an employee to have a concurrent employment and global assignment at the same time, you will need to adjust your processes accordingly to prepare for this change.

Please feel free to reach out and leave a comment below this blog post if you have any questions or need further clarification on this process. Your feedback is always welcome!

entry.title: Re: BAdI/User Exit for Billing Document Creation (VF01 –...
entry.content:
The key challenge here I could see is in S/4HANA Cloud, workflow events are typically raised after the document is saved, because business events like BillingDocument.Created are published post-commit. However, your requirement is to intervene before final save, so the document goes for approval before completion.

Some recommended approaches can be

Enable Flexible Workflow for Billing Documents and check if Billing Document Workflow Scenario is available in your system (via Fiori app Manage Workflows for Billing Documents). If not available, consider using Custom Business Object or Developer Extensibility.

Configure the workflow so that when a billing document of type RE is created, it enters a draft or pending approval state. The workflow is triggered before final posting. This ensures the document is not finalized until approved.

If standard workflow doesn’t support pre-save interception, use BAdI SD_BILLING_DOCUMENT_PREPARE available via Custom Logic App in Fiori. You can raise a custom event or set a flag to block save until approval.

entry.title: How to Handle Cross-Global Account Subscriptions and Customer-Managed HANA in CAP SaaS?
entry.content:
A SaaS solution built using SAP CAP (Node.js) with MTX-enabled multitenancy is currently running in production with several subscribed tenants (subaccounts under the same global account).

The solution is deployed as an MTA in a provider subaccount, while each customer has a dedicated subscriber subaccount to consume the application.

HANA setup

At the moment, I use a shared HANA Cloud database. The MTX sidecar creates a Service Manager HDI container for each tenant, and together with the CDS framework, it handles multitenancy properly.

Customer concern

One customer raised data privacy concerns, since the solution connects to their S/4HANA system (via Cloud Connector) and stores data in our HANA Cloud.

My questions

Part 1: Is it possible for a customer to subscribe to the SaaS application from a subaccount in a different global account (not the same global account as the provider subaccount)? I am particularly thinking about potential XSUAA-related challenges here.

Part 2: Is it possible to support a “bring your own HANA” (BYO HANA) model, where the CDS framework would connect to a customer-managed HANA instance instead of the shared one?

I understand this may be a stretch given the current state of CAP applications, but I’d appreciate any insights into what SAP offers in terms of architectural possibilities and limitations in this area.

Thank you !

entry.title: Re: SAP Build Apps JS Problem
entry.content:
Hello there, this seems to be a js syntax mistake rather than an issue with the custom js block in SAPBA. 

You return your value as `return { myObj }`. Which if you would log that to the console result in the following structure: 

```

{ "myObj": { "urgency": "", ...  } }

```

Instead of your expected output where you defined a structure like: 

```

{ "urgency": "", ... }

```

So the proposed solution is to replace your `return { myObj }` with the `return myObj` line simply. 

However, let me give a few more tips here on the custom js in SAPBA, for things like this, you probably would have been better off with using a 'set app variable' function with a formula like this: 

```

DECODE_JSON(appVars.aiInput[1].content.urgency)

```

By doing it with the filters instead of js you spare yourself some of the tricky aspects of the custom js. 

Lastly, if you really want to use the custom js, then note the following: 

1. The output is most robust if returned as an array of objects (list of objects), e.g. `return [0, myObj]`. Why? Because in SAPBA there is the possibility to define multiple outputs from the cutom JS, e.g. one for success, one for error, one for default output etc. You can see prime examples of this with essentially any data related logic item in SAPBA. 

2. Master the output schema definition. They way you defined the output is just right, to make the best use of the custom js, one has to be good at defininng the variable schemas in SAPBA, especially when it comes to list of things. 

3. Best practice, rename the input properties to something you will remember and understand in the future. Every property that you define on the left side will become a property of the `inputs` object. You are accessing it via the `inputs.input1` path, which is fine, but a slightly more readable and maintainable option would be to do the following: `const { input1 } = inputs;` This destructuring helps in making sure you have more readable and maintainable code, as you would reference this new variable instead of the inputs object always. Just imagine if you would have here a 40-90 line js block and would need to find a typo... 

 

Hope this helps and good luck with SAPBA.

entry.title: Extensibility Custom Field - Professional services - Project billing - PDR to BDR
entry.content:
I have a requirement to Create a custom field in (Professional services -> Project billing cycle ) using Manage Project billing App, the Target is to transfer Data from Project Billing Request ( PDR ) to Billing Document Request ( BDR ) and I have added the fields successfully into project billing and billing request Documents, but the data is not transferred from PDR to BDR

I have followed this blog:  influence-resource-related-billing-through-extensibility-from-journal-entry 

I have created a custom field in the Accounting Coding Block to be visible in the manage project billing App and enabled business scenario Coding Block to Billing Document Item for Project Billing

  1. Three more fields got Created for the following business context
    1. Entries for Project Billing Element (PROJECT_BILLING_ELEMENT_ENTRY) :
      • enabled business scenario -> Coding Block to Billing Document Item for Project Billing 
    2. Items for Project Billing Request (PROJECT_BILLING_REQUEST_ITEM):
      • enabled business scenario -> Coding Block to Billing Document Item for Project Billing 
    3. Sales: Billing Document Item (SD_BILLINGDOCITEM) :
      • enabled SAP GUI User interface so that the value be visible on billing request UI

I filled the custom field value in the manage project billing accounting document entry item level and the data is saved in PDR successfully but not transferred to BDR

entry.title: Re: Can't create Transport Request for my new ABAP Cloud...
entry.content:
This is a change in ABAP Cloud Release 2508. It is no longer possible to create transport requests for packages in software component ZLOCAL (which includes having ZLOCAL as a superpackage). 
It is a logical change, as local developments are not intended for transport, and brings the use of ZLOCAL in line with the use of the analogous package $TMP in on-premise systems, where change recording was also not enabled.

entry.title: Re: Compensation Route map - Configuration
entry.content:
Hi @ImaneRi95 

Compensation is a planner centric module so whichever HR you add to the workflow itself will always be the HR of the planner.

For that reason the leading practice is to grant HRBPs access to their scope through Executive Review.

With the enhancement from 2H 2024 where we can now trigger Executive Review access based on steps of the workflow you could have a step called HRBP where all worksheets go back to Comp Admin and configure this feature in a way that HRBP Exec review access automatically gets triggered once comp forms reach that step (you can even trigger it for a certain amount of days, see note in the blog linked above).

All the best, 

Xavier

entry.title: Re: How to change selected attibute price via action on S...
Usage of parameter "icm/HTTP/mod_X" in a multiple system/client architecture
entry.content:
Dear SAP colleague,

I would like to have your advise regarding usage of Web Dispatcher parameter icm/HTTP/mod_X and redirects.txt file please


We are using a Load Balancer that is placed in front of a Web Dispatcher.
This Web Dispatcher is placed in front of two S/4HANA 2023 systems, DEV (DS4) and QAT (QS4).

Basically this setup:
LB => WebDisp => DS4
                               => QS4

Load Balancer is responding the following name, by doing so that it is redirecting flows to the appropriate Web Dispatcher port:
https://DS4.sap.yyy.com redirects flows to DS4 Web Dispatcher port
https://QS4.sap.yyy.com redirects flows to QS4 Web Dispatcher port

DS4 and QS4 contains multiple clients, we want to use Web Dispatcher parameter icm/HTTP/mod_X to redirect flows to a specific client.

The goal we want to achieve is:
- For DS4:
-- https://DS4.sap.yyy.com/ : Redirect to DS4 backend server https://<DS4 server>.sap.yyy.com:44380/sap/bc/ui2/flp?sap-client=110
-- https://DS4.sap.yyy.com/client100 : Redirect to DS4 backend server https://<DS4 server>.sap.yyy.com:44380/sap/bc/ui2/flp?sap-client=100
-- https://DS4.sap.yyy.com/client110 : Redirect to DS4 backend server https://<DS4 server>.sap.yyy.com:44380/sap/bc/ui2/flp?sap-client=110
-- https://DS4.sap.yyy.com/client120 : Redirect to DS4 backend server https://<DS4 server>.sap.yyy.com:44380/sap/bc/ui2/flp?sap-client=120
-- https://DS4.sap.yyy.com/client130 : Redirect to DS4 sbackend server https://<DS4 server>.sap.yyy.com:44380/sap/bc/ui2/flp?sap-client=130
- For QS4:
-- https://QS4.sap.yyy.com/ : Redirect to QS4 backend server https://<QS4 server>.sap.yyy.com:44380/sap/bc/ui2/flp?sap-client=100
-- https://QS4.sap.yyy.com/client100 : Redirect to QS4 backend server https://<QS4 server>.sap.yyy.com:44380/sap/bc/ui2/flp?sap-client=100
-- https://QS4.sap.yyy.com/client200 : Redirect to QS4 backend server https://<QS4 server>.sap.yyy.com:44380/sap/bc/ui2/flp?sap-client=200
-- https://QS4.sap.yyy.com/client300 : Redirect to QS4 backend server https://<QS4 server>.sap.yyy.com:44380/sap/bc/ui2/flp?sap-client=300

This is how we configured icm/HTTP/mod_X to achieve this in Web Dispatcher:
- icm/HTTP/mod_1 = PREFIX=/, FILE=/usr/sap/WS1/SYS/profile/redirects.txt
- icm/HTTP/mod_2 = PREFIX=/client100, FILE=/usr/sap/WS1/SYS/profile/redirects.txt
- icm/HTTP/mod_3 = PREFIX=/client110, FILE=/usr/sap/WS1/SYS/profile/redirects.txt
- icm/HTTP/mod_4 = PREFIX=/client120, FILE=/usr/sap/WS1/SYS/profile/redirects.txt
- icm/HTTP/mod_5 = PREFIX=/client130, FILE=/usr/sap/WS1/SYS/profile/redirects.txt
- icm/HTTP/mod_6 = PREFIX=/client200, FILE=/usr/sap/WS1/SYS/profile/redirects.txt
- icm/HTTP/mod_7 = PREFIX=/client300, FILE=/usr/sap/WS1/SYS/profile/redirects.txt

And redirects.txt file content is:
if %{HTTP_HOST} regimatch "DS4.sap.yyy.com"
RegIRedirectUrl ^/ /sap/bc/ui2/flp?sap-client=110
RegIRedirectUrl ^/client100(.*) /sap/bc/ui2/flp?sap-client=100
RegIRedirectUrl ^/client110(.*) /sap/bc/ui2/flp?sap-client=110
RegIRedirectUrl ^/client120(.*) /sap/bc/ui2/flp?sap-client=120
RegIRedirectUrl ^/client130(.*) /sap/bc/ui2/flp?sap-client=130
if %{HTTP_HOST} regimatch "QS4.sap.yyy.com"
RegIRedirectUrl ^/ /sap/bc/ui2/flp?sap-client=100
RegIRedirectUrl ^/client100(.*) /sap/bc/ui2/flp?sap-client=100
RegIRedirectUrl ^/client200(.*) /sap/bc/ui2/flp?sap-client=200
RegIRedirectUrl ^/client300(.*) /sap/bc/ui2/flp?sap-client=300

 

Could you tell me what you are thinking about these icm/HTTP/mod_X parameters and redirects.txt file setup please ?

Best regards

Hugo

entry.title: Re: Cannot access script variable in calculation editor f...
entry.content: Sorry. I have not noticed that, you are using it for Calculated Dimension. You cannot use a script variable directly inside a calculated dimension, because calculated dimensions are processed by the data engine before the script runs. Instead, use an input control or HANA/BW variable (which the script can update), and then reference that in the calculated dimension.

entry.title: Re: How to change selected attibute price via action on S...
entry.content: Yes, sbslmhmt, the pricing field on each value within each product attribute. So, for example, if you have an attribute "ATTR", if you make it free entry, you can set its value using your script, and its pricing field can simply contain: "<*VALUE(ATTR)*>".

entry.title: Re: Pricing - Condition activate with requirements
entry.content:
Hi @EdoTama ,

If you have to implement any coding for "repricing automatically" then something is wrong. Do not do this.

What do mean with "i entered a row in sales order"? If this means that you enter a new sales order item, then the following might be relevant:

  • SAP executes item pricing for the new item.
  • SAP does not execute pricing for the whole document. This improves performance.
  • Pricing for whole document is automatically executed when either the order is saved or the header condition screen is displayed. Only afterwards all pricing is correct, especially group conditions and conditions that use group conditions as base.

I can assure you that the use of condition value formulas for deactivating conditions types works reliable. 
If you still have issues, then post the code of the condition value formula, the customizing of the relevant part of the pricing procedure and the customizing of the condition type.

Recommend reading:

  • 3323529 - SD pricing: Standard behaviors guide and How-to scenarios - SAP for Me
  • SAP Pricing: The Condition Technique with SAP | Book a - by SAP PRESS

entry.title: 5 pontos essenciais para um bom fechamento da fase PREPARE em projetos SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private
entry.content:
Quando pensamos em metodologias ágeis e estruturadas, o SAP Activate se destaca como o guia que orienta cada etapa de um projeto de implementação SAP. E dentro desse ciclo, a fase PREPARE tem um papel fundamental: é o momento em que garantimos que toda a fundação esteja sólida antes de avançar para o Explore.

Um fechamento bem-feito da fase PREPARE pode significar a diferença entre um projeto ágil, sustentável e bem-governado — ou um projeto cheio de riscos que surgirão logo adiante.

O Roadmap da metodologia SAP Activate apresenta informações bem completas para apoio nesse momento. Mas caso precise de um guia para referência rápida, deixo abaixo os 5 pontos chave que devem ser considerados neste momento. Como mais referências, deixo ao final deste post o link para o Roadmap completo.

1. Confirmação da Estrutura de Governança

A fase PREPARE deve encerrar com uma governança clara e funcional:

  • Comitês definidos (Steering Committee, PMO, etc.)

  • Responsabilidades bem distribuídas entre cliente, integrador e SAP

  • Regras claras para escalonamento de riscos, problemas e mudanças

 

2. Mobilização Completa da Equipe

É essencial confirmar que todas as equipes-chave estão mobilizadas:

  • Time de projeto do cliente e do parceiro

  • Definição dos Key Users e SME’s

  • Confirmação de disponibilidade e papéis atribuídos

 

3. Ambientes Técnicos Disponíveis

No encerramento do PREPARE, deve-se assegurar que a paisagem técnica mínima esteja pronta:

  • Ambientes DEV, QAS e acessos configurados

  • Usuários habilitados para os Fit-to-Standard

  • Integrações prioritárias mapeadas

4. Plano Detalhado de Atividades do Explore

Fechar o PREPARE significa entrar no Explore já com uma agenda clara:

  • Cronograma dos workshops Fit-to-Standard

  • Métodos e ferramentas de captura de requisitos (ex.: Signavio, Solution Manager)

  • Plano de comunicação e gestão de mudanças

5. Riscos e Dependências Formalmente Registrados

Por fim, todos os riscos identificados até aqui devem estar registrados, categorizados e com planos de mitigação:

  • Dependências externas (infraestrutura, dados, contratos)

  • Desafios de capacitação da equipe

  • Restrições de orçamento e disponibilidade

Conclusão

Encerrar bem a fase PREPARE não é apenas um marco formal — é a garantia de que o projeto seguirá com agilidade, previsibilidade e foco no sucesso.

Com governança estruturada, equipe mobilizada, ambientes prontos, plano detalhado e riscos mapeados, a jornada rumo ao Explore se torna muito mais sólida e segura.

O resultado? Um projeto pronto para evoluir junto com a tecnologia e para entregar o valor de negócio esperado com o SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.

Link para o Roadmap SAP Activate relacionado a esta etapa:
https://me.sap.com/roadmapviewer/group/658F507A-D6F5-4B78-9EE1-0300C5F1E40F/roadmapcontentpage/a11ec6d657054bf9:FA163EAF25B21EEB8FC47DE9E72888DB

entry.title: Integrated Financial Planning CAPEX Delta Planning Data Action
entry.content:
Hello All,

Could anyone please help me with this? I’m reviewing the standard code for the data action Delta Planning in CAPEX. While executing the first part of the code using trace points/debugging, I’m unable to understand the logic behind the value that appears in the AMOUNT_DELTA measure (750).

Can someone assist me in figuring out how this value is being derived?

this is the logic I am debugging in standard code of calculating depreciation delta amount 

//-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
//Set Configurations Definitions for the Advanced Formulas.
//------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
CONFIG.HIERARCHY.INCLUDE_MEMBERS_NOT_IN_HIERARCHY = [d/SAP_ALL_COMPANY_CODE], [d/SAP_FI_IFP_GLACCOUNT], [d/t.S:SAP_ALL_COSTCENTER], [d/t.S:SAP_ALL_PROFITCENTER]
//-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
//The data region against which the formulas will be executed.
//-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
MEMBERSET [d/Measures] = "AMOUNT_DELTA"
MEMBERSET [d/Date] = [d/Version].[p/StartDate] TO [d/Version].[p/EndDate]
VARIABLEMEMBER #RESIDUAL_VALUE OF [d/Measures]
VARIABLEMEMBER #CUMMUL_VALUE OF [d/Measures]
//-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
//Calculation and Data Writing
//-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
//FOREACH [d/Date]
// Staight-Line Depreciation Method: Cummulative Acquisition Value * Depriciation Percentage / 12 Periods
IF RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures] = "DEPR_METHOD", [d/Date] = [d/Version].[p/StartDate], [d/t.S:SAP_ALL_COSTCENTER] = "#") = 1 THEN
DATA([d/Measures] = "AMOUNT_DELTA",[d/SAP_FI_IFP_GLACCOUNT] = [d/SAP_FI_IFP_GLACCOUNT].[p/DepreciationAccount]) =
RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures] = #CUMMUL_VALUE, [d/Date] = PREVIOUS(1)) *
RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures] = "DEPR_PERCENTAGE", [d/Date] = [d/Version].[p/StartDate], [d/t.S:SAP_ALL_COSTCENTER] = "#") / 12
ENDIF

entry.title: 5 Essential Points for a Successful Closing of the PREPARE Phase in SAP S/4 Cloud Private Projects
entry.content:
When we think about agile and structured methodologies, SAP Activate stands out as the framework that guides each stage of an SAP implementation. And within this cycle, the PREPARE phase plays a fundamental role: it is the moment to ensure the foundation is solid before moving forward to Explore.

A well-executed closure of the PREPARE phase can mean the difference between an agile, sustainable, well-governed project — or one full of risks that will appear soon after.

The SAP Activate Methodology Roadmap provides comprehensive information to support this stage. However, if you need a quick reference guide, below are the 5 key points that should be considered at this moment. For additional references, I’ve included at the end of this post the link to the full Roadmap.

1. Confirmation of the Governance Structure

The PREPARE phase must close with a clear and functional governance in place:

  • Steering Committee, PMO, and other bodies defined

  • Roles and responsibilities distributed between customer, integrator, and SAP

  • Clear escalation paths for risks, issues, and change requests

2. Full Team Mobilization

It is essential to confirm that all key teams are mobilized:

  • Customer and partner project teams

  • Identification of Key Users and Subject Matter Experts (SMEs)

  • Commitment and availability validated for each role

3. Technical Landscapes Available

At the closure of PREPARE, the technical environment must be ready:

  • DEV, QAS systems and initial connections configured

  • Access granted to all users involved in Fit-to-Standard workshops

  • Initial priority integrations mapped

4. Detailed Explore Phase Plan

Closing PREPARE means starting Explore with a clear agenda of workshops, deliverables, and acceptance criteria:

  • Full schedule of Fit-to-Standard workshops

  • Methods and tools for capturing requirements (e.g., SAP Signavio, Solution Manager, templates)

  • Change management and communication plan defined

 

5. Risks and Dependencies Formally Registered

Finally, all risks identified so far must be formally documented and mitigated:

  • External dependencies (customer infrastructure, master data, third-party contracts)

  • Training and knowledge curve challenges for the project team

  • Budget and availability constraints

Conclusion

Properly closing the PREPARE phase is more than a formal milestone — it ensures the project moves forward with agility, predictability, and a focus on success.

With structured governance, mobilized teams, available systems, a detailed plan, and documented risks, the journey into Explore becomes much more solid and reliable.

The result? A project ready to evolve with technology and deliver the business value expected from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.

Link to the SAP Activate Roadmap related to this phase:
https://me.sap.com/roadmapviewer/group/658F507A-D6F5-4B78-9EE1-0300C5F1E40F/roadmapcontentpage/a11ec...

entry.title: Blog Post : Integrate SAP Document AI with SAP Build Process Automation on a Trial Account
entry.content:
Introduction

In today's digital world, automating document-heavy processes is key to improving efficiency and accuracy. Manually extracting data from invoices, purchase orders, or delivery notes is time-consuming and prone to errors. This is where the powerful combination of SAP Document AI and SAP Build Process Automation comes into play.

SAP Document AI uses machine learning to intelligently extract structured data from unstructured documents. SAP Build Process Automation allows you to design, build, and run automated workflows. By integrating these two services, you can create robust automations that read, interpret, and process documents just like a human would, but faster and without fatigue.

In this blog post, we will walk through the steps to integrate these two services on a trial account, using a standard invoice schema to extract data.

Prerequisites

  • An active SAP BTP Trial Account.
  • Access to SAP Build Process Automation in your trial subaccount.
  • Basic familiarity with the SAP Build Process Automation studio.

Step 1: Subscribe to SAP Document AI

The easiest way to get started with SAP Document AI on SAP BTP is by using the booster tool.

  1. Log in to your SAP BTP Trial Account cockpit.
  2. Navigate to your Subaccount and go to the Booster.
  3. Search for "SAP Document AI" and click on Start.
  4. Run the booster. It will automatically:
    1. Subscribe you to the service.
    2. Create a service instance and a service key.
  5. Once the booster completes, go to your Subaccount -> Instances and Subscriptions.
  6. Find your newly created service instance for SAP Document AI and navigate to its Service Keys. Open the default service key.
  7. Crucial: From the JSON of the service key, note down the following values. You will need them in the next step:
    1. uaa.clientid
    2. uaa.clientsecret
    3. uaa.url
Note: To access the SAP Document AI service on the browser (e.g., to check schemas or test manually), ensure your user has the appropriate roles assigned by the booster, such as Document_Information_Extraction_Viewer.

Step 2: Generate an Access Token in your Automation

To call any SAP Document AI API, you need a valid OAuth access token. We will generate this using the client credentials from the service key.

  1. In your SAP Build Process Automation project, create three String variables:
    1. uaaUrl (Value: The uaa.url from your service key)
    2. clientId (Value: The uaa.clientid from your service key)
    3. clientSecret (Value: The uaa.clientsecret from your service key)
  2. Create a fourth variable to hold the combined client ID and secret, encoded in Base64. Name it clientInfo.
  3. Use a Script activity to construct the request for the access token. Set the Output parameter of this script to a variable of type Any (e.g., optionsGet).
    1. Script Code for Access Token Request:
return {
    method: 'GET',
    url: uaaUrl + '/oauth/token?grant_type=client_credentials',
    responseType: 'json', 
    resolveBodyOnly: true,
    headers:{
        Authorization:'Basic ' + clientInfo
    }
};
  • After this script, use an Rest Call Web Service activity.
  • The response contains an access_token field. Extract this token into a new string variable or directly pass it to the variable. The value should be:
    1. "Bearer " + step2.obj.access_token

Step 3: Upload a Document for Processing

Now that we have an access token, we can upload an invoice document for processing. We will use the pre-built SAP_invoice_schema.

  1. Ensure you have the path to your invoice file stored in a variable (e.g., fileObj).
  2. Use another Script activity to construct the multipart/form-data request for document upload. The output will be your request configuration.
  3. Use an Rest Call Web Service activity to execute this request.
    1. Script Code for Document Upload:
// Define the extraction options
let optionsPayload = {
    documentType: "custom",
    schemaName: "SAP_invoice_schema", // Using the pre-built schema
    // Below commented values are optional, if you want you can use as per requirement.
    //headerFields: ["deliveryNoteNumber", "purchaseOrderNumber", "deliveryDate"],
    //lineItemFields: ["materialNumber", "quantity", "unitOfMeasure"],
    clientId: "default"
};

// Construct the HTTP request options
let requestOptions = {
    method: "POST",
    url: "https://aiservices-trial-dox.cfapps.us10.hana.ondemand.com/document-information-extraction/v1/document/jobs",
    responseType: "json",
    resolveBodyOnly: true,
    metadataType: irpa_core.enums.request.metadataType.formData, // Crucial for file upload
    headers: {
        Authorization: access_Token // Use the variable from previous step
    },
    metadata: [
        {
            name: "file",
            file: fileObj, // Variable holding the file path
        },
        {
            name: "options",
            value: JSON.stringify(optionsPayload)
        }
    ],
    timeout: 30000 // Set a longer timeout for file upload
};

return requestOptions;​
  • From the uploadResponse, extract two crucial values:
    1. The job id (e.g., into jobId). You will need this to check the result.
    2. The initial status. It will be 'PENDING', meaning the AI is processing the document.

Step 4: Retrieve the Extracted Data

Processing with AI is not instantaneous. We need to poll the service until the status changes from PENDING to DONE.

  1. Create a Data Type: First, create a simple Data Type (e.g., ExtractionResult) with two fields:
    1. Status (Type: String)
    2. Data (Type: Any)
  2. Create a Variable: Create a variable (e.g., finalResult) of this custom type ExtractionResult.
  3. Set Initial Value: Initialize this variable. Set Status to 'PENDING' and leave Data blank.
  4. Build the Polling Request: Create a Script activity to build a GET request to check the job status. The output will be used in an HTTP Request.
    1. Script Code for Retrieving Job Status/Result:
let requestOptions = {
    method: "GET",
    // Use the jobId from the upload step in the URL
    url: "https://aiservices-trial-dox.cfapps.us10.hana.ondemand.com/document-information-extraction/v1/document/jobs/" + jobId,
    responseType: "json",
    resolveBodyOnly: true,
    headers: {
        Authorization: access_Token, // Re-use the same access token
        'Cache-Control': 'no-cache'
    }
};
return requestOptions;​
  • Implement the Polling Loop:
    1. Drag a Forever Loop into your workflow.
    2. In the loop's Condition, use the expression: finalResult.Status !== 'PENDING'. This means the loop will break as soon as the status is no longer 'PENDING'.
    3. Inside the loop:
      1. Use a Wait activity (e.g., wait for 2 seconds) to avoid making too many API calls.
      2. Use the Rest Call Web Service activity with the configuration from the script above. Store the output in a temporary variable (e.g., pollResponse).
      3. Use a Set Variable activity to update finalResult.Status with pollResponse.status  with pollResponse.
    4. The loop will continue until the status in the API response changes to 'DONE'. Once it breaks out of the loop, finalResult.Data will contain the fully extracted invoice data!

You can now use the extracted data in the subsequent steps of your automation, such as filling a form or triggering another process.

The Flow will look like this:

Conclusion

Congratulations! You have successfully integrated SAP Document AI with SAP Build Process Automation. You have built an automation that can submit documents for processing and patiently wait for the AI to return the extracted structured data. This pattern can be applied to countless use cases involving invoices, contracts, forms, and more, unlocking significant potential for automation within your business processes.

This is just the beginning. You can explore creating custom schemas tailored to your specific document types for even more precise extraction.

Feel free to connect here or on LinkedIn for any questions or suggestions.

LinkedIn : Indrajit Shah
LinkedIn : Aditi Jain

entry.title: Why Unite Chose an SAP Business Network, Promote Subscription to Unlock New Opportunities
entry.content:
Unite is a European B2B platform with an integrated marketplace headquartered in Germany that offers a wide range of goods for indirect spend from pre-vetted, pre-integrated suppliers, allowing customers the option for tailor-made purchases or to manage their tail spend. Having been on SAP Business Network for several years, Unite recently subscribed to the new SAP Business Network, promote subscription to differentiate themselves and have a 3rd party verified account, allowing them to be seen as a trusted supplier by prospective customers. 

Founded in 2000, originally as Mercateo, Unite has been proudly serving customers for 25 years helping them enhance their businesses with better procurement. Now, operating in a market that’s more competitive than ever and facing global macroeconomic challenges means that Unite needed to find more ways to get their business discovered by new customers and build new strategic relationships. 

Zachary Rubio Grundell, Strategic Sales Lead, Unite: “Deepening our partnership with SAP through the new SAP Business Network, promote subscription allows Unite to use yet another lever to meet customers where they operate, and increase our discoverability for business growth.” 

The decision to purchase a promote subscription was easy for Unite, as it enabled them to improve their discoverability and create greater awareness of their offerings.  SAP Business Network customers, some of the world’s largest buying organizations, use the network every day to search for new sources of supply. Unite’s profile (Figure 1) and SAP Business Network catalog feature (Figures 2 and 3), a master catalog of products that suppliers can upload, are both searchable by all of SAP Business Network’s global customers, including those not currently purchasing from Unite, giving them greater visibility to potential customers.  

Figure 1: Unite’s company profile on SAP Business Network 

The promote subscription gave Unite access to a network of procurement professionals actively searching for suppliers, along with tools to track opportunities and showcase their capabilities. The network catalog allows them to get discovered by new customers they otherwise wouldn’t have been exposed to and grow their business. 

 

Figure 2: Product preview for one of Unite’s network catalog listings 

Zachary Rubio Grundell, Strategic Sales Lead, Unite: “The process was seamless from decision to execution, and as it was all self-service, timelines were completely within our control. We opted to load an initial list of top selling products from each of our main product categories to ensure an adequate depth and breadth for selection. We are excited to see the results from this initiative within the next few months!” 

Purchasing a promote subscription was easy for Unite, taking just minutes. They were able to verify their profile, independently fill in the provided templates for their network catalog, resolve errors from system prompts where needed, and publish their network catalog of currently 6,067 items across many product categories.  

 

Figure 3: Network catalog management dashboard 

Unite is currently exploring the promote subscription insights to better understand how their profile and network catalog items are performing and gain better market insights. Their team is especially focused on leveraging the platform’s notifications and lead tracking to stay proactive with buyers. Unite is looking forward to continuing to maintain and develop their network catalog and find more customers on SAP Business Network. 

Are you ready to grow your business like Unite? Contact our Supplier Growth Team to learn how your business can connect with new customers and win new opportunities.

entry.title: Success Connect: Your People Deserve More Than Just Software - They Deserve Success
entry.content:
Hello, SAP Community!

From Chief Human Resources Officers to HRIS managers to frontline people leaders, HR professionals at every level are navigating an increasingly complex talent landscape. The pressure to create exceptional employee experiences while driving measurable business outcomes has never been greater. Your organization's success depends not just on having the right technology, but on strategically leveraging that technology to transform how you attract, develop, and retain talent. SAP Business Technology Platform and the SAP SuccessFactors HCM Suite work together to help you achieve exactly that.

For Part 2 of this blog series on SAP Connect 2025, I'm excited to spotlight Success Connect 2025. It will provide CHROs with the next steps to focus on strategic workforce transformation, while delivering deep technical content for HRIS managers and HR technology professionals who implement and optimize these solutions daily.

If this is the first time you're hearing about SAP Connect 2025, read this blog first.

 

 

HR Going Beyond Traditional Boundaries

Today's HR leaders face unprecedented challenges. Regardless of your industry or organization size, you're expected to be data scientists, morale builders, strategic business partners, and technology innovators—all while maintaining the employee experience that defines great HR. On top of that, HR leaders are also faced with major obstacles in preparing their workforce for AI. With all these rapid changes in technology, the workforce’s generational differences, and your organization’s moving goals, where do you go from here?

 

By integrating, extending, and automating your SAP SuccessFactors solutions and processes, SAP Business Technology Platform doesn't just support your organization—it evolves it into what it was meant to be. This enables your existing HR processes to transform into the proactive talent strategy that drives measurable business value. Check out  SAP.com/btp-for-HR page for more in-depth information on how SAP BTP helps deliver better and more efficient HCM processes.

Here are my five must-attend sessions at Success Connect that will expand how you think about HR technology possibilities:

 

 

Your must-attend sessions at Success Connect

 

Scenario 1: Integration

 

Your Challenge: HR processes span multiple systems— the SAP SuccessFactors HCM suite and third-party applications —creating fragmentation that leads to inefficiencies, data errors, and poor employee experiences. Read about the related use case here. 

The Solution: Discover how SAP Integration Suite enables seamless connections between SAP SuccessFactors HCM Suite and your entire HR ecosystem. Explore integration use cases for recruiting, onboarding, and data collection, plus strategies for connecting hybrid landscapes with legacy on-premises systems. See how SAP Integration Suite, Advanced Event Mesh enables you to monitor your event-driven system and manage various aspects of your event-driven architecture. Learn to automate immediate responses for hiring, role changes, and other critical workforce events.

Business Impact: Interconnected HR processes eliminate manual data entry, reduce the time needed to onboard new employees by 50%, and create consistent employee experiences regardless of underlying system complexity. Event-driven integration ensures new employees have system access on day one, eliminates security risks from delayed termination processing, and creates seamless workforce transitions.

If this is you, these sessions should be on your agenda:

 

Maximizing HCM Process Efficiency with Integration Through SAP BTP | HCM1665

Tuesday Oct 7 | 11:15 AM – 12:00 PM PDT

How to Use Event-Driven Integration to Collaborate in Real Time | HCM1682

 Wednesday Oct 8 | 12:30 PM – 12:50 PM PDT

 

 

Scenario 2: Automation

 

Your Challenge: Your employees and HR teams spend valuable time on repetitive tasks, such as managing employee data and records, handling routine processes and more, instead of focusing on strategic HR activities that drive employee engagement and retention. Read about the related use case here. 

The Solution: Explore automation capabilities that streamline recruiting, onboarding, document management, and HR workflows. Learn how SAP BTP helps reduce manual errors while freeing your team to focus on high-value activities that directly impact employee experience.

Business Impact: HR process automation typically reduces administrative overhead by 60% while improving accuracy and employee satisfaction with HR services.

If this is you, this session should be on your agenda:

 

Increasing Employee Efficiency with Automation Capabilities in SAP BTP | HCM1671

 Wednesday Oct 8 | 10:00 AM – 10:45 AM PDT

 

 

Scenario 3: Extensibility and app Development

 

Your Challenge: Your workforce needs mobile access to different HR services, but standard solutions don't address your unique requirements or user experience preferences. The existing processes are prone to errors, making it hard to gain insights from the data. Read about the full use case here. 

The Solution: Explore building a custom mobile app using SAP Build solutions. These solutions make developing an application tailored to your workforce needs intuitive, even for non-technical users. 

Business Impact: With SAP Build's low-code capabilities, a customized application can be built 10 times faster. 

If this is you, this session should be on your agenda:

 

Hands-On Lab: Creating a Custom Mobile App for HR Using SAP Build Solutions | HCM1677

  • Tuesday Oct 7 | 3:30 PM – 4:45 PM PDT
  • Wednesday Oct 8 | 1:00 PM – 2:15 PM PDT

Additionally, a simplified version of the hands-on lab topic of creating a mobile app is being demonstrated at the Integrate and Extend with SAP BTP demo station in the HCM area, when the show floor is open

Enhancing People Profiles with SAP Business Technology Platform | HCM1520

Wednesday Oct 8 | 2:45 PM – 3:30 PM PDT

 

 

Additional sessions that should be in your agenda:

 

AI Technology, use cases and innovation

 

Road map and vision: AI in SAP SuccessFactors HCM | HCM1451

  • Tuesday Oct 7 | 11:15 AM – 12:00 PM PDT
  • Wednesday Oct 8 | 2:45 PM – 3:30 PM PDT

Unlocking and extending the Joule copilot with Joule Studio | HCM1571

Tuesday Oct 7 | 12:45 PM – 1:30 PM PDT

Everything you need to know about AI agents for HCM | HCM1468

Tuesday Oct 7 | 2:00 PM – 2:45 PM PDT

 

 Employee experience via integration and extensibility

 

Drive productivity by integrating and extending your HCM solutions | HCM1081

Tuesday Oct 7 | 4:15 PM – 5:00 PM PDT

 

Technology and administration

 

Fortifying together: Best practices for partner and customer security | HCM1061

Tuesday Oct 7 | 10:00 AM – 10:45 AM PDT

Simplifying your system administration to maximize business continuity | HCM1106

Tuesday Oct 7 | 2:00 PM – 2:45 PM PDT

Road map and vision: Application and technology foundation | HCM1030

Tuesday Oct 7 | 3:15 PM – 4:00 PM PDT

 

 

 

Register Now: Your HR Transformation Starts Here

Success Connect 2025 isn't just about learning new capabilities—it's about positioning your HR organization to lead in the talent-driven economy that's already here. You will gain practical strategies you can implement immediately to transform your HR technology investments into competitive advantages.

Register now for Success Connect 2025 and join the community of HR leaders who are turning people technology into people success. Here’s a great blog from my colleague @rnoia  on SAP BTP for HR at SAP Connect and Success Connect 2025 summary.

 

What's Coming Next in This Series

In the next blog post, I’m joining forces with my colleague Isabelle Joaquin @ijoaquin to dig deeper and provide our recommended sessions for Spend Connect 2025. But don’t let that stop you from registering and checking out the event agenda to see all the sessions offered at Connect here and register!

entry.title: Re: Network Assignment on VBEP-AUFNR gets deleted due to...
entry.content:
Please note VBEP-AUFNR is linked to confirmed schedule lines. When credit check fails, Confirmed quantities (VBEP-BMENG) may be reset to zero. This triggers a reinitialization of schedule lines. If AUFNR was assigned based on confirmed quantity or ATP result, it gets wiped.

Go to OVA8, find the entry for your sales document type and credit control area, Check the reaction code. If it’s set to B or C, consider changing it to A (Check without block) for testing purposes. This allows the system to perform the credit check but not block the order, so you can observe whether AUFNR gets assigned properly.

entry.title: Re: Network Assignment on VBEP-AUFNR gets deleted due to...
entry.content:
Go to vov7, select your item category and see the “Schedule line allowed” checkbox is enabled for the item category used in your sales order.

Go to transaction VOV6 and check for the following fields

  • Availability Check: Should be active if AUFNR is assigned during ATP.
  • Confirmed Quantity: If this is reset due to credit block, AUFNR may be cleared.
  • Relevance for Delivery: Impacts whether schedule lines are retained or refreshed.

If the schedule line is configured to depend on confirmed quantity, and credit block resets that quantity, AUFNR may be lost.

Go to transaction OVZ9 to review the availability check procedure. This combines the checking group (from the material master) and checking rule (from the transaction). Ensure ATP is not overly restrictive or disabled in a way that prevents AUFNR assignment.

entry.title: Re: AR Invoice showing incorrect stock quantity
entry.content:
The reasons could be

since INV1.U_KD_BRNG_PJK is defined as Alphanumeric (length 20), it is stored as a string, not a number. If your query is trying to treat it as a number (e.g., using SUM, CAST, or numeric comparison), it may default to 0 if the string isn't parsed correctly.

The value 281100 may look clean in the UI but contain leading/trailing spaces, non-printable characters (e.g., carriage return, tab), invisible formatting from copy-paste or integration. These can cause SQL functions to misinterpret the value.

If your query includes a WHERE clause or joins that filter out the invoice, it may return 0 because the row is excluded. Double-check that the invoice number is included in the query result set.

Since this issue occurs only in one invoice, compare it with others where the query works. Look for differences in how the UDF was populated — manually vs. via integration, copy-paste, etc.

entry.title: Re: Discrepancy in TDS Deduction During CN Booking
entry.content:
TDS is calculated based on Withholding Tax Type, Withholding Tax Code, Vendor Master Data & Invoice Posting Date. If the CN uses a different posting date, tax code, or vendor configuration, SAP may default to the standard rate (2%) instead of the LDC rate.

Check if the LDC validity period covers the CN posting date. If the CN was posted outside the LDC window, SAP will apply the default rate.

Go to FK03 or BP and check withholding tax code assigned to the vendor, whether the LDC rate (1.35%) is correctly maintained and whether the CN posting logic bypasses or overrides this setup.

entry.title: Need Help
entry.content:
The client requires a report of the actual weights provided by the warehouse after the goods have been packed and the entire pallet has been weighed. The macro adjusts the discrepancies between the actual weight and the SAP weight by proportionally adding or subtracting kilograms from the SAP weight for each line item on the given pallet. This adjustment is made proportionally for each reference on the pallet.
For below example, if the actual weight is 10 kg less than the SAP weight, the macro will subtract 8 kg proportionally from reference PN A and 2 kg from PN B.
We are unable to set the actual weight directly in SAP because there are deviations in the weight of individual references. The client does not accept these deviations and wants the actual pallet weight to be reflected accurately. Therefore, we need to adjust the weight per reference so that the totals sum up correctly.
The macro adjusts the weights proportionally across all products on a given pallet based on the difference between the actual measured weight and the SAP weight.
It then recalculates the quantities into pieces (gross/net), assuming a tare weight of 25 kg.
 
For example, if a pallet weighs 510 kg in SAP but actually weighs 500 kg, and contains:
    PN A – 410 kg
    PN B – 100 kg
After running the macro, the adjusted weights become:
    PN A – 402 kg
    PN B – 98 kg
How can we implement this so we can see actual weight on invoices????
